item.title: Redneck
item.dc:creator: @JavaTC JavaTC
item.description:
@JavaTC wrote:

Did anyone even watch his response to Dr. Phill? He said he wasn’t proud of what he had done, but it’s to late now. He went viral, and there’s nothing he can really do to stop it. He never really ruined his daughter’s life, it would be the mass amount of overreacting people spreading it around that would’ve ruined it if anyone. People act like parents should be perfect at parenting, when really, it’s a learning curve for both the parents and the child.

I do think that teens should be aloud to express their opinion on the way their parents are parenting, but at the same time, they shouldn’t have the say in the way they do their jobs. I get sick of people saying “Wow you said one bad thing about your parent, you need to be punished”. I don’t think parent’s should get super special treatment just because they’re your parents.

I believe you need to respect them considering all that they give you, but you shouldn’t be forced into agreeing with all their morals and beliefs, like many think.

item.title: Redneck
item.dc:creator: @Tom Tom
item.description:
@Tom wrote:

hat trix:

The reason we all agree with what he has done is because most of us have grown up to the extent that we don’t sympathize around small children’s poor choices. It was parenting to say the least, and a lot of children (especially in america) don’t even get that.

What we define as parenting comes from our own life experiences, we all don’t grow up and then reach the conclusion that one thing exactly is good parenting. Anything is parenting, but defining whether it was good parenting is another point.

People don’t just grow up and then know how to be a good parent, hell, there probably isn’t even a solid definition of good parenting. Everything in this world depends on belief progression and personal experience, which can be effected by age but not completely.

Where do you draw your especially in America point from again?

hat trix:

Time will pass, she will grow older and sooner or later forgive her father for what he has done, as her father will forgive her for what she has done. People will go on about their lives and it will quit haunting her within the years. There was no serious harm done. And the people that wont forget it are usually the every day bully she was already dealing with.

So your real argument is “It’ll only worsen her life for all her teenage years!”. I guess that makes it okay then. The most influential years of a females life when a lot of her personality will be put into action, and she becomes vulnerable ad unstable as she adapts to a new way of life due to growth and so forth.

On top of that she now has this to deal with this, an increase in bullying, low self esteem and confidence problems. Let us explore each point:

[ul][li]Increase bullying - Over 5.7 million teens in the USA experience bullying, now I’m going to speak from some field experience here, when I was younger I was attacked for things that weren’t really my fault (verbally) they had a field day at times about it. If something like this happened to me, I don’t know what I’d do.[/li][/ul]

My parents, the ones who were supposed to stop the bullying and support me, are the ones actually fueling the fire. Now, I understand it would be my fault but I’d expect a little better from my parents, I’d expect them to respond to the situation in a more adult way than I did. The parents responding the same way she acted didn’t teach her anything, it’s treating her like a dog.

Let us look at extreme cases as well, if things went really bad, this could even stretch as far as suicide. The thing is, none of us know the extent of her personal issues or any background issues. You may say there is a small chance of this ever happening, but would you risk your childs demise anyway?

Example of what bullying can cause: http://www.care2.com/causes/10-year-old-girl-commits-suicide-after-intense-bullying.html

Now in this point I speak from experience, as above, the damage I’ve had done to my confidence in earlier life still hasn’t gone away and that was more than 6 years ago. I don’t think people understand how much of a bad experience the dent gives you for a huge part of your life.

It restricts what you’re able to do as a person, and halts personal progress. Most people think you just wake up one morning and it’s gone. Well, it aint that simple. So I think you’ll find serious harm is done in the end.

If you loved your child, you would not wish to put them through what would be caused by his actions. The idea of putting them through it for the greater benefit of themselves is silly, there are other ways to go about such a situation which achieve the same end effect.

item.dc:creator: @Tom Tom
item.description:
@Tom wrote:

Anyhow, such a response from her parents isn’t acceptable. Consider the social ramifications of what he has done, and how that will damage her mentally. She has been humiliated in front of every person she knew, and internet strangers, that is in no way acceptable what so ever. She will lack confidence for a large portion of her life, it is one thing making an example out of her in private but publicly doing it (in front of what turned out to be millions of people, with people then leaking private information about her).

As I’ve said earlier on in this thread none of us are aware of the methods that her father used in order to obtain the information about what she posted on Facebook so further arguing on such a point would be silly.

It’s not about what he could have done, he has humiliated his daughter completely, it isn’t a good parenting technique it’s bullying to say the least. Also, about the chores point, I’m going to play the Devils Advocate here. You do realize that it boils down to his word against hers, this situation can easily be turned on its head and she could be telling the truth.

Don’t give me this crap about parents being more believable either, if the guy was to abuse her then he would be willing to lie about the entire thing. There simply isn’t sufficient grounds to argue much here. Still being a child myself (16, so probably not even a year older than her), and living with my parents, I would generally never forgive them if they were to do such a thing to me. I would act like it was fine after a while, but the bitterness inside would never go away.
